item.description:
Hello, I am a Ph.D. student and National Science Graduate Research Fellow in the Department of Electrical & Computer Engineering at the University of Washington (UW).

“Garbage in, garbage out” is a phrase that describes a common pitfall in computing. The rapid improvements in computing systems and artificial intelligence offer tremendous opportunities for finding meaning in large, complex data sets. However, the outputs of these systems–and the trust that they garner–are only as good as they data that goes in. My research seeks to produce high-quality data that can be used to formulate high-quality decisions.

My work has included measuring biologically harmful radiation from space to improve aviation safety while working at NASA as well as measuring neural ensemble activity in the brain to develop revolutionary treatments at the UW Center for Neurotechnology.

The focus of my dissertation is on novel wireless sensing systems that improve our ability to measure and interpret challenging phenomena, like neural activity. Common wireless solutions, like Bluetooth and WiFi require far too much power (did you realize that nearly half your phone is a battery?). By reducing the size, weight, and power needs of our wireless sensors, we can enable exploration of diverse, extreme environments, from the brain to the solar system.

Much of my work has been on embedded-electronics and instrumentation hardware for government, industry, and academic research. Examples include nanosatellite avionics, ultra-low power wireless brain-computer interfaces, and a radiation sensing system for high-altitude balloons.

I strongly believe that publications alone are not enough to communicate with the public, especially for tax payer-funded research, therefore it is our responsibility as researchers to provide full-value to the public and earn their support through STEAM outreach, mentoring, and community service.

For an overview of my experience, see my CV. For more details on my work, check out my Publications and Projects on this site. If you have any questions, don't hesitate to reach out.
